metadata.sermon_title: Second Sunday After Pentecost: Psalm 130 / 2 Corinthians 13
metadata.notes: The sermon combines a Trinitarian blessing with a deep dive into the concept of total depravity and mercy.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher utilizes a 'Theological CP' to enforce the concept of 'miserable offenders' and 'no health in us.' While framed as honesty, it uses dogmatic pressure to invalidate the listener's sense of self-worth.
quotes: there is no health in us
none of us can hold up our heads

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The Nurturing Parent is strong, using the imagery of a desperate parent to illustrate God's love. However, it risks being 'smothering' by suggesting the listener is a 'self-destructing child.'
quotes: You would make a complete fool of yourself if you thought it might get your child’s attention.
the Someone who is eternal and inexhaustible, yet personal, relational, and intimately loving

adult.analysis: The preacher provides historical and linguistic context (Adult data), but then uses that data to steer the listener back into a Child position (the 'miserable offender').
quotes: The last four chapters of 2 Corinthians form the most agonized portion of the New Testament.
We need to compare this benediction at the end of 2 Corinthians with those in his other letters.

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The sermon explicitly invites the listener into the 'Adapted Child' role—specifically the 'compliant/guilty' mode. It suggests that health is found only in admitting total wretchedness.
quotes: Out of the depths have I called to you
Lord, have mercy on me, a sinner

free_child_FC.analysis: There is a glimpse of the Free Child in the 'ecstatic imagery' of the watchman and the 'joyous and liberating knowledge,' though it is strictly regulated by the preceding guilt.

ego_positions_scan.dominant_ego_position: Nurturing Parent (Rescuer) transitioning to Critical Parent (Persecutor of the ego).

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher speaks as a wise, concerned Parent (NP/CP) to a congregation positioned as a struggling or 'self-destructive' Child. The transaction is stable because the religious context rewards this dependency.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: Social: 'Let us study the Trinity.' Psychological: 'You are fundamentally broken and must admit it to be loved.'
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The 'double bottom' is the Bait & Switch: starting with the 'love of God' (NP) to lower defenses, then pivoting to the 'miserable offender' (CP) to secure compliance.

detected_games.name: Bait & Switch / Redemption

formula_g_analysis.con: The promise of a 'full Trinitarian blessing' and 'self-giving love.'
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's desire for parental-style unconditional love.
formula_g_analysis.switch: The shift to the necessity of the 'miserable offender' label and 'no health in us.'
formula_g_analysis.payoff: The listener feels small/guilty (Payoff) but 'saved' by the preacher's formula.

evidence_quotes: The church that was breaking his heart is the one that gets the full Trinitarian blessing.
The depth of which the psalmist is actually speaking here is the depth of the knowledge that he and everyone else is a 'miserable offender.'

detected_games.name: ITHY (I'm Only Trying To Help You)

formula_g_analysis.con: Preacher as the one who restores the 'powerful buttress' of the old prayer book.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's sense of 'something being wrong' with the world.
formula_g_analysis.switch: The diagnosis that the listener has 'no health' in them.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: The preacher maintains the role of the necessary guide to the 'path of life.'

evidence_quotes: The removal of this line has robbed us...
This is not self-abasement leading to paralysis; this is honesty leading to deliverance.

preacher_roles.rescuer: High. The preacher offers the 'Trinitarian formula' and the 'path of life' to the 'self-destructive' listener.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Medium. Manifests through the insistence on the 'miserable offender' status and the critique of modern prayer books for being too soft.
preacher_roles.victim: Low. Only appears vicariously through the description of Paul's 'agonized' state.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: Victim. The congregation is framed as the 'anorexic/drug-addicted child' or the 'miserable offender' who cannot stand without help.
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: Low. The sermon suggests that 'honesty' (admitting Victimhood) is the only way out, which actually reinforces the Triangle rather than promoting Adult autonomy.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: The sermon is a classic example of 'Nurturing Parent' rhetoric used to deliver a 'Critical Parent' payload. It utilizes the Drama Triangle by casting the listener as a helpless, self-destructive child (Victim) and God/The Preacher as the Rescuer. While theologically traditional, it relies on the psychological 'Game' of making the listener feel fundamentally 'unhealthy' to make the 'mercy' feel more potent. This creates a dependency loop where the listener must feel bad to feel good.
strengths: Strong use of empathy and relatable parental metaphors.
High Adult-ego engagement in the historical analysis of Paul's letters.
areas_for_improvement: Heavy reliance on shaming language ('miserable offenders', 'no health').
The 'Bait & Switch' from unconditional love to total depravity can be psychologically jarring.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Try to address the congregation from an Adult-to-Adult position. Instead of telling them they have 'no health,' invite them to observe the reality of their lives and the 'here-and-now' effects of their choices. Move away from the Rescuer role by empowering the listener's own agency to respond to grace, rather than insisting on their total helplessness.
